title: Investing in Space: Boeing and SpaceX had a major week that put their differences on display
summary: For longtime readers of Investing in Space, you may notice this newsletter is arriving a day later than typical – my apologies for the delay, but I assume many of you (like me) were watching a livestream or two on what was a historic day for spaceflight.

title: Competing with Uncle Sam’s free space offerings
summary: Convincing customers to pay for Space Domain Awareness and Alt-PNT services over free alternatives remains a challenge.

title: ESA and Vast to study cooperation on future commercial space stations
summary: The European Space Agency has signed an agreement with Vast to study how the agency could use and support the company’s commercial space stations.

title: As leaks on the space station worsen, there’s no clear plan to deal with them
summary: "We heard that basically the program office had a runaway fire on their hands."

title: Space tourism dreams live on
summary: Twenty years ago, SpaceShipOne appeared to open the door to a new spaceflight era. Today, that door is barely ajar.

title: Tools for space sustainability watchdogs
summary: The FCC has made a landmark foray into space debris enforcement but it’s unclear how it would translate greater visibility into action.

title: SpaceX and the categorical imperative to achieve low launch cost
summary: The underlying math of SpaceX's business model suggests that the company is selling Falcon launches at a major markup.

title: Rocket Report: Starliner soars to space station; Starship’s wild flight
summary: "This powerful rocket is the culmination of many years of dedication and ingenuity."

title: AI powering commercial insights into the final frontier
summary: The U.S. Space Force, which is responsible for providing space domain awareness data for military operations, is currently refining its plan to leverage commercial innovations.

title: Boeing’s Starliner CFT Docks with ISS Despite Thruster Issues
